keywords.value: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
keywords.name: organizations

byline.original: By PETER BAKER and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Michael R. Gordon contributed reporting from Shannon, Ireland.

lead_paragraph: Despite mounting evidence that toxic weapons remain in Syria, the president appears no more eager to use military force there than he was in 2013.

headline.print_headline: Traces of Chemicals in Syria Add to Pressure on Obama to Enforce a ‘Red Line’
headline.main: Traces of Chemicals in Syria Add to Pressure on Obama to Enforce a ‘Red Line’

snippet: Despite mounting evidence that toxic weapons remain in Syria, the president appears no more eager to use military force there than he was in 2013.
abstract: Obama administration continues to be reluctant to use military force against Pres Bashar al-Assad's Syrian government, despite discovery of chemical agents strongly indicating ongoing presence of toxic weapons; American and other Western intelligence analysts speculate that Assad regime hid small stockpiles of banned toxins, but is awaiting further investigation from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons.
